description:
She earns about S$5, or 70,000 rupiah on good days - barely enough to scrape by.

Indonesian single mother Puryanti bows stiffly like a robot, as she and her five-year-old son, their bodies gleaming in silver paint, appeal to passersby for an occasional coin at a busy intersection outside the capital Jakarta.

They are among a group of people dubbed "manusia silver", or "silver people", who are doing this to make ends meet after the coronavirus pushed Southeast Asia's largest economy into recession last year.

"I am not ashamed to work like this," says Puryanti. "The important thing is this is all for my children."

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Reuters
#manusiasilver #silverpeople #art #indonesia #unemployment #work #economy #jobs

description:
For avid travellers who actually miss airplane food - especially the grub served onboard Japan Airlines.

You can now order their ‘inflight meals’ at Japan Rail Café, located at Guoco Tower in Tanjong Pagar. 

For the month of January, the travel-themed café has partnered with JAL to offer its most popular economy-class meals featured on its Singapore-to-Japan flights.

Click on the link in bio @todayonline, for all the details.

description:
He was upset that others had received Budget 2020 grocery vouchers and he had not, so he stole S$600 worth of these vouchers from his neighbours’ letterboxes.

But Alvin Law Choon Huat, 47, later received the vouchers himself, too. 

Law told the court that he was caught in a bind when he received his vouchers after stealing his neighbours’. “If I bring (the stolen vouchers) to the police, I would be arrested. So I mixed them together, bought a little food for my family and the rest, I burnt them,” he said through a Mandarin interpreter.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#budget2020 #voucher #singapore

comments: proud of this dude and hopes he succeeds
description:
Mr Mohamad Zaid Rahmat, 34, has always admired nurses for their steadfast dedication to their profession.

While in his second year of undergraduate studies, he contemplated dropping out of his real estate degree course to switch to studying nursing, but was dissuaded from doing so by his mother.

Upon graduation, Mr Zaid went on to join the civil service, where he helped plan and manage the budget for a government organisation.

However, a series of events reignited his determination to join the more than 100,000 healthcare professionals across both public and private sectors. 

About a year ago, he joined the Professional Conversion Programme (PCP), an initiative that helps Singaporeans make the transition to a career in healthcare.

Learn more about why he took this plunge, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#professionalconversionprogramme #healthcareworkers #healthcareprofessional #nurse #sghealthcare #healthcare #singapore

While in his second year of undergraduate studies, he contemplated dropping out of his real estate degree course to switch to studying nursing, but was dissuaded from doing so by his mother.

However, a series of events reignited his determination to join the more than 100,000 healthcare professionals across both public and private sectors.

description:
“Stripped of all the bells and tinkles, it is perhaps a blessing” for Christians as the quieter celebrations provide them with a chance to reflect on the true meaning of Christmas, said a spokesperson for the archbishop's communications office at the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Singapore.

“We are also encouraged to reflect on the first Christmas, where Christ was born without fanfare and only the angels and the shepherds, along with their sheep, bore witness to his birth.”

As Christians get ready to celebrate the birth of Jesus Christ today, the familiar hymns and carols that would typically resonate through church halls during Christmas festivities will be largely heard online due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

The various churches interviewed by TODAY said that while they have gradually raised the limits of the number of worshippers allowed within their premises, in accordance with government guidelines, there are some people who are more comfortable worshipping from home because of the global health crisis.

Religious organisations have been allowed to admit up to 100 people since Oct 3 — with safe distancing and management measures in place. This limit is due to be raised to 250 people, in five zones of up to 50 people each, when Singapore enters the final phase of reopening its economy on Dec 28.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#merrychristmas #christmas #churchservice #christmas2020 #covid_19 #churchlife #sgchurch

description:
Mr Firdaus Abdul Hamid, 40, is the co-founder of non-profit organisation Human Hearts @humanhearts.sg , which helps inmates, ex-convicts, families of incarcerated individuals and at-risk youths find support.

Unbeknownst to many, Mr Firdaus could do with a helping hand himself. 

The pandemic has cost him his marine engineering job and forced him to take up odd jobs which include cleaning work, on top of having to care for his pregnant wife and three children aged between 14 and 10.

“Yes, of course, it’s difficult for me. But I want to help people who think they can’t be helped. With the resources that I have, it’ll be a waste if I don’t,” he said. 

The pandemic and its devastating impact on the economy have affected many people’s lives and livelihoods, casting a gloom over the entire year. But this has not deterred ordinary Singaporeans like Mr Firdaus from stepping up to bring joy to others. 

These community volunteers distribute food, clean up homes, shelter the homeless and spread cheer — all the while navigating the pandemic restrictions. Some of the volunteers’ brave fronts also mask the struggles that they are going through themselves due to the pandemic...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#givingback #givingbacktothecommunity #community #volunteer #communityvolunteer

description:
Coming to you, Jan 2021.

Swedish furniture giant Ikea is opening a three-storey outlet at Jem mall in Jurong next year. But that’s not the only branch it is opening in the Jurong neighbourhood — it is also launching a “planning and renovation studio” at Jurong Point in January 2021.

But don’t expect a massive homeware shopping haven for the Jurong Point studio. It appears to be solely for interior design consultancy, as it occupies a modest two-unit space near a McDonald’s outlet.

According to the store hoarding, which is still up, the studio is a collaboration with Bangalore-based interior design firm Livspace. On Livspace’s website, it calls itself Ikea’s “official renovation partner in Singapore”, and customers can head to Ikea’s existing two outlets at Alexandra and Tampines for a free consultation with an interior designer.

Ikea’s website also offers “budget-friendly” HDB BTO packages that handle everything from “design to installation” of Ikea furniture...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#ikea #ikeasingapore @ikeasingapore #livspace @livspacesg #homeandliving #homeimprovement #homewaresg

comments: We are always in for more affordable renovation for sg households! Nevertheless don’t forget to do your renovation research. Your first home renovation is a pretty sizable investment and make sure well spent 👍🏻🇸🇬❤️

On Livspace’s website, it calls itself Ikea’s “official renovation partner in Singapore”, and customers can head to Ikea’s existing two outlets at Alexandra and Tampines for a free consultation with an interior designer.

Ikea’s website also offers “budget-friendly” HDB BTO packages that handle everything from “design to installation” of Ikea furniture...

When Singaporean singer-songwriter Derrick Hoh, 35, flew to Taiwan to pursue his music career, he was shocked by their culture of vying for media attention and having to go on variety shows to promote himself. He wasn’t comfortable with this, but soldiered on.

“It was pretty tough for me during the [first two to three years of my] time there,” Derrick admitted, as he opened up about the early days of his career on the latest episode of Quan Yifeng’s @quanyifong talk show, Hear U Out.

“I’d receive NT$1,350 (S$64) for every TV appearance I made," he revealed. Even then, not all of the S$64 would go to him. As most of it was kept by his label to pay off his debt, Derrick would only have about NT$200 (S$9.50) a day to spend. 

“I also had to take into account the money I had to pay for getting my hair styled as well as my traveling costs. I had to budget everything myself,” he shared. “Sometimes, I’d manage to save NT$50 (S$2.30) after a few days and I’d buy a bowl of iced grass jelly for myself. That was the highlight of my week."

Through that and various other hardships, Derrick held on to his dream. He says it's because of one person: his older sister.

“She wanted to be a dancer, but she told me that she wouldn’t be able to fulfill this dream in this life," said Derrick, fighting back his tears. "She saw that there was an opportunity for me to be a singer and pursue a career that I like, and...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photos: Derrick Hoh's Instagram @derrickhoh, Derrick Hoh's Twitter, Mediacorp

#derrickhoh #singersongwriter #singersongwritersg

description:
When Singaporean singer-songwriter Derrick Hoh, 35, flew to Taiwan to pursue his music career, he was shocked by their culture of vying for media attention and having to go on variety shows to promote himself. He wasn’t comfortable with this, but soldiered on.

“It was pretty tough for me during the [first two to three years of my] time there,” Derrick admitted, as he opened up about the early days of his career on the latest episode of Quan Yifeng’s @quanyifong talk show, Hear U Out.

“I’d receive NT$1,350 (S$64) for every TV appearance I made," he revealed. Even then, not all of the S$64 would go to him. As most of it was kept by his label to pay off his debt, Derrick would only have about NT$200 (S$9.50) a day to spend. 

“I also had to take into account the money I had to pay for getting my hair styled as well as my traveling costs. I had to budget everything myself,” he shared. “Sometimes, I’d manage to save NT$50 (S$2.30) after a few days and I’d buy a bowl of iced grass jelly for myself. That was the highlight of my week."

Through that and various other hardships, Derrick held on to his dream. He says it's because of one person: his older sister.

Denmark's Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen broke down earlier this week when visiting a mink farmer, who lost his herd following the Danish government's order this month to cull all 17 million mink in the country to curb the spread of coronavirus.

The government has since admitted that the order to cull the country's entire mink population was illegal. 

The order was given after authorities found Covid-19 outbreaks at hundreds of mink farms, including a new strain of the virus, suspected of being able to compromise the efficacy of vaccines.

"We have two generations of really skilled mink farmers, father and son, who in a very, very short time have had their life's work shattered," Ms Frederiksen told reporters after a meeting with a mink farmer and his son at their farm near Kolding in Western Denmark.

"It has been emotional for them, and... Sorry. It has for me too," Ms Frederiksen said with a wavering voice, pausing for breath in between words.

Denmark's mink population is one of the world's biggest and highly valued for the quality of its fur. The head of the Danish mink breeders' association has said that the industry, which employs around 6,000 people and exports fur pelts worth US$800 million (S$1,071 million) annually, is finished.

Denmark's Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen broke down earlier this week when visiting a mink farmer, who lost his herd following the Danish government's order this month to cull all 17 million mink in the country to curb the spread of coronavirus.

The government has since admitted that the order to cull the country's entire mink population was illegal. 

The order was given after authorities found Covid-19 outbreaks at hundreds of mink farms, including a new strain of the virus, suspected of being able to compromise the efficacy of vaccines.

"We have two generations of really skilled mink farmers, father and son, who in a very, very short time have had their life's work shattered," Ms Frederiksen told reporters after a meeting with a mink farmer and his son at their farm near Kolding in Western Denmark.

"It has been emotional for them, and... Sorry. It has for me too," Ms Frederiksen said with a wavering voice, pausing for breath in between words.

Denmark's mink population is one of the world's biggest and highly valued for the quality of its fur. The head of the Danish mink breeders' association has said that the industry, which employs around 6,000 people and exports fur pelts worth US$800 million (S$1,071 million) annually, is finished.

description:
Ever since the Malaysia-Singapore border closed in March this year, businesses in what is popularly known as the Johor Baru (JB) city centre have suffered.

Before the shutdown, this was a lively area where you could find restaurants and other businesses open until the wee hours of the morning.

Now, businesses are not only suffering from the lack of Singaporean shoppers but also from restrictions put in place because of Covid-19 standard operating procedures.

Says Mr Lyas Lee, the owner of popular downtown eatery Retto Cafe along Jalan Ibrahim: "I was close to closing my business as we could not cope with the situation (during the lockdown)."

However, the 34-year-old entrepreneur tried his best to hold on as he felt it was a shame to let go of a premium spot in the city centre. Currently, he is earning far less than before...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Malay Mail 

#malaysia #johorbahru #jb #business #businessowner #covid_19 #economy #border 
Read more at https://www.todayonline.com/world/jb-businesses-hoping-better-tomorrow-once-singaporeans-can-cross-over-again

description:
Ever since the Malaysia-Singapore border closed in March this year, businesses in what is popularly known as the Johor Baru (JB) city centre have suffered.

Before the shutdown, this was a lively area where you could find restaurants and other businesses open until the wee hours of the morning.

Now, businesses are not only suffering from the lack of Singaporean shoppers but also from restrictions put in place because of Covid-19 standard operating procedures.

Says Mr Lyas Lee, the owner of popular downtown eatery Retto Cafe along Jalan Ibrahim: "I was close to closing my business as we could not cope with the situation (during the lockdown)."

However, the 34-year-old entrepreneur tried his best to hold on as he felt it was a shame to let go of a premium spot in the city centre. Currently, he is earning far less than before...

description:
Be prepared. There is a lot to take in. 

Every Singaporean aged 18 and over will receive $100 in SingapoRediscovers Vouchers from Dec 1, 2020 to Jun 30, 2021.The $100 can be used for tours, attraction tickets and staycations bookable at five authorised platforms. There are also physical booths set up islandwide to help those who need assistance to set up their SingPass accounts, or to book experiences. 

Each adult Singaporean can redeem up to six child/youth subsidies (that's a $10 discount per child/youth ticket) for family members aged below 18. 

How to redeem the vouchers online? Tip: Have your Singpass details ready. 

Step 1: Start shopping for experiences on one of the five authorised booking partners’ websites. Eligible products are marked with the SingapoRediscovers Vouchers icon.

Step 2: Select the experiences and dates you wish to book and add to cart. When you’re ready to pay, click on ‘Use SingapoRediscovers Vouchers’ at checkout. 

Step 3: Log in with SingPass...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#singapore #voucher #singaporediscovers #singaporediscoversvouchers

Every Singaporean aged 18 and over will receive $100 in SingapoRediscovers Vouchers from Dec 1, 2020 to Jun 30, 2021.The $100 can be used for tours, attraction tickets and staycations bookable at five authorised platforms. There are also physical booths set up islandwide to help those who need assistance to set up their SingPass accounts, or to book experiences. 

Each adult Singaporean can redeem up to six child/youth subsidies (that's a $10 discount per child/youth ticket) for family members aged below 18. 

How to redeem the vouchers online? Tip: Have your Singpass details ready. 

Step 1: Start shopping for experiences on one of the five authorised booking partners’ websites. Eligible products are marked with the SingapoRediscovers Vouchers icon.

Step 2: Select the experiences and dates you wish to book and add to cart. When you’re ready to pay, click on ‘Use SingapoRediscovers Vouchers’ at checkout. 

Step 3: Log in with SingPass...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#singapore #voucher #singaporediscovers #singaporediscoversvouchers

comments: I want go hotel 81
description:
Singapoliday time! 

Each Singaporean aged 18 and above (as of 2020) will get $100 in SingapoRediscovers Vouchers that can be used for attraction tickets, hotel stays and local tours in Singapore from Dec 1, 2020 to June 30, 2021. These will be distributed in denominations of $10.

There are five authorised online platforms to redeem the vouchers: Changi Recommends, Trip.com, Klook, GlobalTix, and Traveloka. You will need to use your SingPass account to claim your vouchers.

For those who are unable to redeem their vouchers digitally, there will be physical touchpoints set up by booking platforms. STB is also working with the People’s Association to set up physical booths at some community centres (CCs).

Where can you use your SingapoRediscovers Vouchers?
There are over 200 merchants where you can use those SingapoRediscover Vouchers — 37 attractions, 164 hotels and 79 tour operators are on the list at press time.

For the full (and very handy) list of the attractions, hotels and local tours you can use your SingapoRediscovers Vouchers at, click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Unsplash 

#singapore #singaporediscovers #voucher #supportllocal #supportlocalsg

description:
Singapoliday time! 

Each Singaporean aged 18 and above (as of 2020) will get $100 in SingapoRediscovers Vouchers that can be used for attraction tickets, hotel stays and local tours in Singapore from Dec 1, 2020 to June 30, 2021. These will be distributed in denominations of $10.

There are five authorised online platforms to redeem the vouchers: Changi Recommends, Trip.com, Klook, GlobalTix, and Traveloka. You will need to use your SingPass account to claim your vouchers.

For those who are unable to redeem their vouchers digitally, there will be physical touchpoints set up by booking platforms. STB is also working with the People’s Association to set up physical booths at some community centres (CCs).

Where can you use your SingapoRediscovers Vouchers?
There are over 200 merchants where you can use those SingapoRediscover Vouchers — 37 attractions, 164 hotels and 79 tour operators are on the list at press time.

For the full (and very handy) list of the attractions, hotels and local tours you can use your SingapoRediscovers Vouchers at, click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Unsplash 

#singapore #singaporediscovers #voucher #supportllocal #supportlocalsg

description:
While working as a cleaner, he heard a woman whisper to her daughter: “Ah Girl ah, if you always spend time on these things, you’ll end up sweeping the floor like that Kor Kor (big brother, or me).”

‘’I am sure many of us have heard our parents or seniors make similar statements,’’ says this letter writer. 

‘’But being on the receiving end of one made me wonder why we are quick to pass judgement on certain professions or individuals. I have always believed that people should not be defined by their qualifications or occupation, but by who they are and how they behave.’’

Yet, he adds, there are still professions in our society that are judged and ostracised.

He feels that in light of the disruptions brought about by Covid-19, the need for empathy in our society is greater than ever. 

‘’I believe that being more empathetic towards those around us can help forge a happier community and a more robust economy. We are stronger together,’’ he says. 

Read on, when u click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
Singapore may be on the other side of the Pacific Ocean, but the election buzz can be clearly felt among the American community here — and even among many Singaporeans.

Republican nominee Donald Trump and Democratic candidate Joe Biden have offered starkly different views of America and the world. Mr Trump and his running mate Mike Pence face Democratic candidates Joe Biden and Kamala Harris, with the latter team currently leading in most opinion polls.

Ms Tina Datta chairs the Republicans Overseas Singapore. Her organisation is the Republican Party’s official association for its citizens living outside America. 

Having heard what Singaporeans had to say of her party’s nominee over the years, Ms Datta noted that youths are often focused on his environmental policies, while business folk are more concerned about the global economy and how Mr Trump has pulled the United States out of regional trade pacts.

Most Trump naysayers here take issue with the combative tone of his politics, she says. 

“But when I start talking about actual policy, there is actually a broad understanding here of American policy — why there is a need to put pressure on China, why the US needs a tough stance on illegal immigration, et cetera,” said Ms Datta. “And it usually resonates with people in Singapore.”

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
Singapore may be on the other side of the Pacific Ocean, but the election buzz can be clearly felt among the American community here — and even among many Singaporeans.

Republican nominee Donald Trump and Democratic candidate Joe Biden have offered starkly different views of America and the world. Mr Trump and his running mate Mike Pence face Democratic candidates Joe Biden and Kamala Harris, with the latter team currently leading in most opinion polls.

Ms Tina Datta chairs the Republicans Overseas Singapore. Her organisation is the Republican Party’s official association for its citizens living outside America. 

Having heard what Singaporeans had to say of her party’s nominee over the years, Ms Datta noted that youths are often focused on his environmental policies, while business folk are more concerned about the global economy and how Mr Trump has pulled the United States out of regional trade pacts.

Most Trump naysayers here take issue with the combative tone of his politics, she says. 

“But when I start talking about actual policy, there is actually a broad understanding here of American policy — why there is a need to put pressure on China, why the US needs a tough stance on illegal immigration, et cetera,” said Ms Datta. “And it usually resonates with people in Singapore.”

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
Not long now! 

By December, it will be compulsory to use the TraceTogether mobile application or token to check in at venues such as workplaces, schools, malls as well as food and beverage outlets under the Government's plan to further reopen the economy.

At these venues, people will not be able to check in by scanning their identification cards or SafeEntry QR codes with their phones, the Smart Nation and Digital Government Office said in a statement yesterday.

Instead, they will have to either use the TraceTogether app to scan a QR code at the premises or have the staff there scan the QR code found on their token.

Currently, only the use of SafeEntry is compulsory.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#trace #tracker #tracetogether #covid_19 #corona #covid #government #sg #app

description:
There are wallet-friendly options too. 

A three-hour 𝗹𝘂𝗻𝗰𝗵 𝗲𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗼𝗻 𝗮𝗻 𝗔𝟯𝟴𝟬 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗲 parked at Changi Airport: 
S$50 on Economy
S$90 on Premium Economy
S$300 on Business Class
S$600 in Suites.

For those who wish to 𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗮 𝗙𝗶𝗿𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗿 𝗕𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗖𝗹𝗮𝘀𝘀 𝗽𝗮𝘀𝘀𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗲𝗿 𝗮𝘁 𝗵𝗼𝗺𝗲, meals can be delivered at S$288 for a Business Class meal for two; and from S$448 for a First Class meal for two.

And for the 𝗯𝘁𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗼𝗸 𝗮𝘁 𝗦𝗜𝗔’𝘀 𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗲, it’s S$30 for adults, and S$15 for kids aged three to 12. All prices include a meal.  There are also additional activities available at an extra charge, such as a flight simulator experience (S$500 for a session for up to 3 people), among others. 

🛬 More details in the link in bio @todayonline. Would you try any of these experiences? 

(📷:@singaporeair )

A three-hour 𝗹𝘂𝗻𝗰𝗵 𝗲𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗼𝗻 𝗮𝗻 𝗔𝟯𝟴𝟬 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗲 parked at Changi Airport: 
S$50 on Economy
S$90 on Premium Economy
S$300 on Business Class
S$600 in Suites.

For those who wish to 𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗮 𝗙𝗶𝗿𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗿 𝗕𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗖𝗹𝗮𝘀𝘀 𝗽𝗮𝘀𝘀𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗲𝗿 𝗮𝘁 𝗵𝗼𝗺𝗲, meals can be delivered at S$288 for a Business Class meal for two; and from S$448 for a First Class meal for two.

And for the 𝗯𝘁𝘀 𝗹𝗼𝗼𝗸 𝗮𝘁 𝗦𝗜𝗔’𝘀 𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗲, it’s S$30 for adults, and S$15 for kids aged three to 12. All prices include a meal.  There are also additional activities available at an extra charge, such as a flight simulator experience (S$500 for a session for up to 3 people), among others. 

🛬 More details in the link in bio @todayonline. Would you try any of these experiences? 

(📷:@singaporeair )

Forget about that overseas vacation (for now).

It's time to holiday in Singapore, with some help from SingapoRediscovers vouchers. 

Every Singaporean aged 18 and over will get S$100 worth of tourism vouchers to spend locally on staycations, attraction tickets and tours. 

How will you receive it? No queueing necessary. You can access the vouchers via your SingPass account - more details are set to be released in November.

When are the vouchers valid from and until? December 2020 to end-June 2021. 
Yes, just in time for the school holidays this December, next March and even next June, so there's no need to rush to use your tourism credits.

What about those under 18? Those above 18 can buy children and youth tickets for attractions and tours at a S$10 subsidy. Each adult is allowed to purchase up to six of such tickets.

More Q / A, in the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Unsplash

comments: @yoongs1009 bro
description:
Oops. 

Imagine receiving 40 copies of the same email, all containing info not meant for you. 

Singapore budget airline Scoot mistakenly emailed customers regarding requirements to undertake a Covid-19 test for a flight bound for Guangzhou, China. 

The email recipients included customers who made no such bookings for the flight.

A spokesperson for Scoot, which is a subsidiary of Singapore Airlines, said that there was no data breach or leak of personal information despite the error.

Read on, at the link in bio @todayonline

comments: Even ex-passenger like my husband who had not booked a scoot flight for many months gets more than 10 emails on that notification.

A spokesperson for Scoot, which is a subsidiary of Singapore Airlines, said that there was no data breach or leak of personal information despite the error.

Read on, at the link in bio @todayonline

Oops. 

Imagine receiving 40 copies of the same email, all containing info not meant for you. 

Singapore budget airline Scoot mistakenly emailed customers regarding requirements to undertake a Covid-19 test for a flight bound for Guangzhou, China. 

The email recipients included customers who made no such bookings for the flight.

A spokesperson for Scoot, which is a subsidiary of Singapore Airlines, said that there was no data breach or leak of personal information despite the error.

Read on, at the link in bio @todayonline

description:
“I have emphasised that integrity and character are very important in our candidates. If there's any complaints, it should be properly clarified,” said Mr Heng Swee Keat, the People's Action Party (PAP) first assistant secretary-general. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Mr Heng called for party new face Ivan Lim to step forward and address online criticisms of him, after a number of negative posts and comments have surfaced on social media since Mr Lim  was introduced as a PAP candidate on Wednesday.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Mr Ivan Lim has since broken his silence on the online criticisms. #linkinbio for the full article.

comments: How do you ensure integrity and character? How will you be able to give us reassurance?  What are the avenues we can report for these issues? I have reported to you, MAS and few of your MPs but all are taking back seats.  My personal experience on LTA public liability claims where the loss adjusters skills , integrity, ethnics  and characters are a big issues but none of you are willing to check on. MAS even tell me they do not regulate loss adjusters. There are no regulators in singapore to "control" the loss adjusters. How do the victims appeal without having the means to engage the lawyers?  曾经在书中看到这样的一个说法"官大吃四方"。我不太认同，但得看那个人的人格吧。害群之马必定有的。真心付出的人，还是有的。 是祸是福，因人而意。

comments: One moment we hear DPM saying he would like to reach out to the individuals who commented on Ivan Lim’s character and examine the concerns thoroughly; the next moment we hear PM Lee saying that the short campaign period simply does not allow time for such investigations. We hear MP Masagos and DPM commenting how candidates should prove/ redeem themselves in election, but no single PAP member seemed to have sufficient proof points to present us with a much needed alternative/ balanced view point of Ivan Lim’s character. The PAP did not appear to have a unified position on how best to handle this saga. Also, why could and did no single PAP member did put up a case for Ivan? Instead most comments were directed to Ivan to speak for himself. Is it time to take a true and deeper review of the PAP’s candidate selection process? Did the candidate already prove themselves to the party sufficiently both in terms of calibre and integrity before the party decided on them being fielded?

description:
The opposition Workers’ Party (WP) unveiled its first slate of four General Election (GE) candidates on Thursday (June 25). They are: • Advertising executive Nicole Seah, who ran in the 2011 General Election under the National Solidarity Party
• Research analyst Louis Chua Kheng Wee
• Gig economy worker Muhammad Azhar Abdul Latip
• Former non-constituency Member of Parliament (NCMP) Yee Jenn Jong 
Meanwhile, the party said that former chief Low Thia Khiang and his fellow Aljunied Group Representation Constituency team member Chen Show Mao, as well as former Hougang MP Png Eng Huat will not be standing as candidates in GE 2020. More details in the #linkinbio

description:
The Government will provide a one-off sum of S$100 to each household with at least one Singaporean citizen to help them to offset their utility bills. ⁣
⁣
This credit will be given out to households living in all property types and will be credited in either the July or August utilities bill.⁣
⁣
The utility rebate is part of the support measures rolled out for households under the S$33 billion Fortitude Budget announced by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat in Parliament on Tuesday (May 26). ⁣
⁣
#linkinbio to learn more.⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣

comments: Nice 😮
description:
Few would have rated her chances of survival when 97-year-old Brazilian Gina Dal Colleto was hospitalised on April 1 with coronavirus symptoms.⁣
⁣
But survive she did, and her unexpected recovery has become a ray of hope in Brazil, where the coronavirus has laid bare a stretched public health system and exposed fierce political debate over how to best tackle the virus' spread and prop up the country's economy. Brazil has reported 1,223 deaths and 22,169 confirmed cases of #covid19 as of Sunday (April 12).⁣
#linkinbio to read more.
